Tiene un local en su casa donde vende encebollados, trabaja todos los días desde las siete hasta las 13h00, sus hijos le ayudan en su negocio el mismo que lo tiene por seis años en el cual ha logrado tener mucha clientela que la prefieren por su sazón, además de encebollados también vende gaseosas, cervezas y jugos de frutas, los productos de fabrica los recibe en su local.
 
Este crédito es para comprar ingredientes necesarios para preparar los deliciosos encebollados. Es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque en cada reunión además de aprender algo nuevo se divierte con sus amigas. Sus sueños son tener su casa propia y su local propio ya que donde vive y tiene su negocio es arrendado.
texts.en:
The 100% Charapote Communal Bank meets in the city of Charapoto every two weeks.  This place is known for its traditional culture.   It is also known for being a few minutes from two of the best beaches, San Jacinto and San Clemente, in the province.

This is where we find Sofía.  She is 35 years old and in a common-law marriage.  She has three children, ages 19, 18, and 12.  The two younger ones are in school.  Her husband is a farmer.  She has a place in her house where she sells “encebollados” (a dish made from fish, onions and cassava).  She works every day from 7:00 a.m. until 1:00 p.m.  Her children help her with her business, which she has had for six years.  She has managed to have a lot of customers who prefer her seasoning.  In addition to selling encebollados, she also sells soft drinks, beer, and fruit juices that are delivered to her place.

This loan is to buy the ingredients needed to prepare the delicious encebollados.  She is a founding member of the communal bank.  She likes it because, in addition to learning something new at each meeting, she has fun with her friends.

Her dream is to have her own house and her own place of business because the place where she lives and has her business is rented.

loans.use:
Buy ingredients to make  
"encebollados" (a dish made from fish, onions and cassava)

loans.name: Angie Marisela

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Charapoto se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal 100% Charapoto. Esta localidad se conoce por su cultura tradicional y además por estar a pocos minutos de dos de las  mejores playas de la provincia como son San Jacinto y San Clemente.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Angie, tiene 21 años de edad, está casada y está en su tercer mes de embarazo de su primer hijo. El marido es chofer de volqueta. Ella es nacida en Guayaquil  pero desde que se caso hace 8 meses se vino a vivir a esta ciudad.

Es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo. Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes. Trabaja cinco días a la semana, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana o cada quince de acuerdo a lo que quieran sus clientes. Su mercadería se la envían desde Guayaquil.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisas, camisetas, blusas, entre otras. Este es el tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos salen rápido y sin tantos requisitos. Sus sueños son seguir trabajando para tener algo mejor para el futuro.
texts.en:
The “100% Charapoto” community bank meets every two weeks in Charapoto which is known for its traditional culture and also for its proximity to two of the best beaches in the province: San Jacinto and San Clemente.

In this town we can find Sra. Angie who is 21 years old. She is married and three months pregnant with her first child. Her husband drives a dump truck. Angie was born in Guayaquil but when she got married eight months ago, she came to live in this town.

Angie is a homemaker but in order to have money of her own she sells clothing from a catalog. Generally she goes door to door to make her sales, but sometimes customers come to the house. She works five days a week. She sells the items on credit and collects the payments every week or every two weeks, depending on the wishes of her customers. The merchandise is sent to her from Guayaquil.

This loan is to buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, blouses etc. This is Angie’s third loan with her bank, and she likes the speed at which the loans are approved and without too much red tape. Her dream is keep on working to secure a better future.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, blouses etc

loans.name: Natalia Del Carmen

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Charapoto se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal 100% Charapoto. Esta localidad se conoce por su cultura tradicional y además por estar a pocos minutos de dos de las  mejores playas de la provincia como son San Jacinto y San Clemente.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Natalia, tiene 21 años de edad, es madre soltera de dos hijos de 5 y un año. Vive en casa de sus padres. Es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta por los beneficios adicionales que brinda la institución y por las facilidades para los créditos, además porque  a través de los créditos ella ha podido financiar su negocio.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo y productos de Esika (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes. Trabaja tres días a la semana, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana, lo que más vende es ropa de mujer  y en Esika lo que es cosméticos y bisutería.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones,  blusas, cremas, cosméticos, bisutería, entre otras. Sus sueños son tener un gran bazar.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the '100% Charapoto' community bank meets in the city of Charapoto.  This city is known for its traditional culture and for the fact that it is located only a few minutes from two of the best beaches in the province: San Jacinto and San Clemente.

Here we meet 21 year-old Natalia.  She is a single mother who has two children aged 5 and 1.  She lives in her parents' home.  Natalia is a founding member of her community bank and she likes it for the additional benefits that they receive from the institution and for the repayment terms.  She also likes it because, through the loans she has received, she has been able to finance her business.

Natalia makes catalog sales of clothes and Esika products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and ladies' accessories).  She makes her sales door to door and also sells from her home where her customers come to buy from her.  She works three days a week.  She leaves her products with her customers on credit and collects payment every week.  The products she sells most of are women's clothes and Esika products (cosmetics and costume jewelry).

Natalia will use this loan to buy pants, blouses, creams, cosmetics, costume jewelry etc.  Her dream is to own a large store.

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, creams, cosmetics, costume jewelry and perfume.

loans.name: Angela Guadalupe

texts.es:
En la parroquia Alajuela del cantón  Portoviejo  se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Alajuela, este sector es conocido por ser una zona donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Angela, tiene 42 años de edad y está separada pero de esa relación tiene cinco  hijos dos mayores de edad y tres  de 17, 15 y 13 años los mismos que estudian en colegio. Está en el Banco Comunal hace dos años y está muy contenta ya que gracias a los créditos ha podido sacar adelante su negocio.
 
Tiene un puesto de comidas rápidas en donde, vende empanadas, corviches y colas, trabaja todos los días  desde las 15h00 hasta las 19h00, además los fines de semana también preparar los deliciosos encebollados y bollos  el cual lo hace en las mañanas desde las 7h00 hasta las 13h00, ella además de vender sus productos en su local también manda a sus hijos a vender por toda la localidad.

Este crédito es para comprar colas, plátano, maní, aceite, pescado y otros ingredientes en la elaboración de sus platos. Sus sueños son tener un gran local para vender sus productos.
texts.en:
In Alajuela Parish of the canton of Portoviejo the members of the Alajuela Communal Bank meet every two weeks. This sector is known as an area where most inhabitants are engaged in agriculture.

In this place, we meet Señora Angela, age 42. She is separated but has 5 grown children from her relationship and three, ages 17, 15, and 13, who are high school students. She has been in the communal bank for two years and is very happy since, thanks to her loans, her business has been able to progress.

She has a fast food stall where she sells empanadas, corviches (dough made from grated plantain, deep fried and stuffed with spicy fish or minced meat, topped with salad, mayo, chili) and soft drinks. She works every day from 3:00 p.m. until 7:00 p.m. and on weekends. In addition, she also prepares delicious stews and buns which she makes in the mornings from 7:00 a.m. until 1:00 p.m. She sells her products at her stall and also sends her children to sell them throughout the area.

This loan is to purchase soft drinks, bananas, peanuts, cooking oil, fish, and other ingredients used to make her dishes. Her dream is to have a big shop for selling her products.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks, bananas, peanuts, cooking oil, fish and more ingredients

loans.name: José Genaro

texts.es:
En la parroquia Alajuela del cantón  Portoviejo  se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Alajuela, este sector es conocido por ser una zona donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura.

En este lugar conocimos a José el tiene 37 años de edad, está soltero y vive en una casa que el arrienda. Este es su segundo ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por las facilidades que brinda la institución para conseguir los créditos, además porque en cada reunión comparte y aprende de las charlas.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  ventas es puerta a puerta y también vende en su  casa, nos cuenta que en temporadas se dedica además a la cría de pollos pero que ahora con la entrada del invierno no lo va a hacer porque hay muchas perdidas por las enfermedades que les da en esta temporada. Trabaja todos los días, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada semana. Su mercadería  la compra  Guayaquil. Lo que más vende es ropa de hombre, pantalones, buzos, camisas.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, buzos, camisas, etc. Sus sueños son tener una tienda.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the "Alajuela" community bank meet in the parish of Alajuela, in Portoviejo canton.  This area is known for the fact that most of its inhabitants are farmers.

Here we meet 37 year-old José who is single and lives in a rental house.  This is his second loan cycle with his community bank and he likes it for the ease with which the institution provides loans.  He also likes it because in every meeting he shares with his fellow group members and learns somehting from the talks they receive.

José sells all kinds of clothes.  He makes his sales door to door and also sells from his home.  He tells us that during some seasons he also raises chickens but now, with winter approaching, he will not pursue this business because there are a lot of losses due to illnesses that the animals suffer during this season.  José works every day.  He leaves his products with his customers on credit and collects payment every week.  He buys his merchandise in Guayaquil.  What he sells most of is men's clothes: pants, track suits and shirts.

José will use this loan to buy pants, track suits, shirts, etc.  His dream is to own his own store.

loans.use: To buy pants, track suits, shirts, etc.

loans.name: Dolores Beneranda

texts.es:
En la parroquia Alajuela del cantón  Portoviejo  se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal Alajuela, este sector es conocido por ser una zona donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura.

Para la señora Dolores este es su cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y nos cuenta que estuvo en la creación del Banco pero tuvo un problema y no pudo tener un crédito pero luego soluciono el problema y nuevamente ingreso en el Banco. Tiene 41 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene 5 hijos tres mayores y dos de 15 y 10 años, ellos estudian y viven aun en su casa. Su esposo es panadero.

Tienen una panadería en el centro de Alajuela en que hacen diversos tipos y sabores de pan, además de pasteles y tortas de cumpleaños, trabajan todos los días desde las 5h00 hasta las 13h00 en la venta pero desde la noche ellos preparan la masa para que en la madrugada ya este todo listo para hornear el delicioso pan, sus hijos le ayudan cuando no tienen muchas tareas que hacer.

Este crédito es para comprar harina, azúcar, sal, y otros ingredientes necesarios para la elaboración del delicioso pan. Sus sueños son que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the "Alajuela" community bank meet in Alajuela parish, in Portoviejo canton.  This area is known for the fact that most of its inhabitants are farmers.

This is Dolores' fourth loan cycle with her community bank and she tells us that she was there when her community bank was founded but that she had a problem and couldn't take a loan.  However, she solved her problem and became a member of the bank again.

Dolores is 41 years old, married, and has 5 children.  Three of her children are already grown up and the other two are 15 and 10 years old and still live at home with her.  Her husband is a baker.

Dolores and her husband have a bakery in the center of Alajuela where they make different types and flavors of bread.  They also make cakes and birthday cakes.  They work every day from 5.00am to 1.00pm selling their products but they prepare their dough at night so that, early in the morning, they have everything ready to bake their delicious bread.  Their children help them when they don't have a lot of other work to do.

Dolores will use this loan to buy flour, sugar, salt and other ingredients they need to make their delicious bread.  Their dream is for their children to become good professionals.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, salt, eggs, butter, etc.

loans.name: Dios Bendice 1 & 2 Group

texts.en: "Dios Bendice 1 & 2" (God Bless) is a group of ten women. Jesimena is the group representative. She is an old woman with five children. When you look at her, you can tell she has been through a lot in her life. She has lived in the same community for many years and, for her entire life, she has been living day to day without a steady income. She is excited to be doing something different and is ready to make a change and start to better her life. She hopes to help her children out of their poverty some day as well. Jesimena plans to invest in her comedor and small restaurant in her batey (or neighborhood) by buying rice, beans, flour, oil, vegetables and meats. She cooks a daily lunch for different people in her community or employers and dreams of having a big restaurant in the nearest town. She will use her business profits to buy chairs and table, because she want to rebuild her local business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Generally, her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: To buy rice, beans, flour, meat, oil, etc.

loans.name: Memena's Group

texts.en:
Memena is the group representative of a group of 15 Haitian women called Dios Bendice 3, 4 & 5. She is the mother of five children. She has lived in the same community for many years after immigrating from Haiti 15 years ago. She is excited to do something different with her life and is ready to make a change and better her life with this loan investment.  She will use her share of this loan to improve her charcoal selling business and to expand to selling other miscellaneous products. She said her most difficult challenge has been to study.  That is why she is making an effort to help her children study and to take care of them.

Memena plans to invest in her charcoal sale business, as well as begin selling other miscellaneous products. She will use her business profits to invest in her new activity.  She wants to start working harder toward having a little store. 

Memena's story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti.   Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and cosmetics products to resell

loans.name: Dios Es Bueno 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Margarita is the coordinator of her group Dios es bueno 1, 2 & 3 (God is great). She makes her home here in a simple structure with four children and her long term partner. She says that her most difficult challenge is to educate and raise her children, in a foreign country, and proviD. what her spouse can't. In the meantime she plans to continue enjoying to cook and have fun with her family by wacthing tv and others.

Margarita is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza. She has had her business for 3 months, starting with her some money she saved, of her family expenses. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing bread, jam, cheese, fruits, sugar, snacks, and others. She will use the profits to buy some present for her children in christmas time and she want to save to reinvest in her business.

This Esperanza associate began with us because she wants to have a business and she was needing the capital to start one. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally, her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominates the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity.

loans.use: to buy bread, jam, cheese, fruits, sugar, snacks, and others

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his business and attract more customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional materials for his general store

loans.name: El Progreso 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
El Progreso 1 & 2 (Progress) is a group of ten people who are all requesting loans with Kiva partner, Esperanza International, and taking a step to improve their businesses. This group comes from an extremely poor area in San Pedro, Dominican Republic. The majority of this group do not have a steady income, and they are looking to start small businesses to change that fact. The group is very excited about this opportunity, and they are ready to get started on their businesses.
Rhut is the representative of this group. She is planning on investing in her business selling shoes and miscellaneous products. She is the mother of three young children, and she wants nothing more than to be able to provide them with a comfortable life. She dreams of sending them to university someday. Rhut is an extremely hard worker who will find a way to make her business work. She is excited to finally be getting a chance, and she admits that opportunities like this haven't come her way often. She is ready to take this next step towards a better life!

loans.use: To buy shoes and other products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To meet all wedding expenses and organize a wedding party for his brother

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To build up her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to build up the business by increasing the stock

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad from Marka, Amman is a 46-year-old married man. He has his own hair-cutting shop. Mohammad is requesting a loan of 500 JD to add skin cleaning products to the product line for his business. His wife (Nadia) who appears in the photo helps him with managing the shop.
Mohammad's aspirations are to purchase a house for his family and to open a new branch for his shop.

loans.use: To add skin cleaning products to the product line for his business

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud from Al Hussein, Amman is 47 years old and has two children. He is an ambitious entrepreneur who has his own shop for take-away food and falafel (a traditional food in Jordan). Mahmoud is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to purchase materials for his shop. He aims to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his shop

loans.name: Tawfeq

texts.en: Tawfeq is a 42-year-old married man from Marka, Amman. He has his own car repair shop and is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to computerize his machines and purchase spare parts for cars. Tawfeq is looking to open a new branch for his shop.

loans.use: To computerize his machines and purchase spare parts for cars

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan from Marka, Amman is 55 years old and the father of two children. He has his own car repair shop after developing good experience in that field.
Adnan is requesting a loan of 500 JD to purchase new equipment for his shop. He is looking to develop his shop and increase his revenue.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment for his shop

loans.name: Manal

texts.en:
Manal from Marka, Amman is a 34-year-old married woman who has one child. She is very talented in fashioning and decorating with flowers which earns her a good reputation in that field although she works from home.
Manal is requesting a loan of 500 JD which is her first loan from Tamweelcom and Kiva. She intends to use the loan to purchase materials for her home-based business. Manal is looking to open her own licensed shop in a reputable area in Amman.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her home-based business

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad from Marka, Amman is 57 years old and the father of three children. He started his business years ago when he was producing a special kind of sweets but he was distributing his products using his own feet. The strong determination and aspiration of Mohammad along with his sons help turned his business into a successful and famous one.

He is requesting a loan of 1000 JD to purchase raw materials and to carry out maintenance on the bus used for his products' distribution. Mohammad is planning to open a shop for his business to increase market exposure. He will then be able to increase his family's income and employ more family members in the business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and to carry out maintenance on the bus used for his products' distribution

loans.name: Sana'a

texts.en:
Sana’a from Al Hashmi, Amman is 44 years old and the mother of four. Benefiting from her exceptional talent in embroidery, Sana’a decided to start a home-based business in fashioning and embroidering items which will provide her family with additional income.

She is requesting a loan of 300 JD to purchase raw materials for her business. Sana’a is aiming to open a licensed shop for her business where she can employ more women to empower them and provide them with financial resources.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her business

loans.name: Dalal

texts.en:
Dalal is 28 years old and is from Al-Bayader, Amman. She has her own home-based business where she makes pottery and decorates with sea shells. Dalal is requesting a loan of 400 JD to purchase materials for her business. 

She is looking to expand her business through participating in Souk Ayyadi (a non-financial service provided to Tamweelcom clients which sells their handmade products through bazaars and permanent showrooms) so that she will gain exposure for her products resulting in increased income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her business

loans.name: Khadejah

texts.en:
Khadejah form Marka, Amman is a 41-year-old married woman. She is an entrepreneurial woman who has a dry-cleaning shop and she is one of the rare women who works in this field.

Khadejah is requesting a loan of 500 JD to buy a new washer to clean bed covers and to buy a steam-ironing machine. She is well known in the area as having a good reputation, and is planning to open a new branch for her shop to meet the increasing demand.

loans.use: To buy a new washer to clean bed covers and to buy a steam-ironing machine

loans.name: Myasar

texts.en:
Myasar from Marka, Amman is a young 23-year-old entrepreneurial woman. She started her business from home selling home-cleaning products, and then she rented a small shop. She is requesting a loan of 400 JD to decorate her shop and to buy additional materials.

Myasar's mother, who appears on the right of Myasar in the photo, is helping her to manage her business. Myasar's aspiration is to build a strong reputation for her shop and increase her sales.

loans.use: To decorate her shop and to buy additional materials

loans.name: Baha'a

texts.en:
Baha’a from Marka-Amman is 28 years old, a married man and the father of one child. He runs a successful cafeteria and is requesting a loan of 1,500 JOD to purchase a new machine and to decorate his shop.

Baha’a is looking forward to opening a new branch for his cafeteria to improve his family's living conditions, and where he can employ one of his family members.

loans.use: to purchase a new machine and to decorate his shop.

loans.name: Karim

texts.en:
Kareem from Marka- Amman is 31 years old, a married man and the father of one child. He is a hard worker and a dedicated man who has a car washing shop.  He is requesting a loan of 1,500 JOD to purchase a new machine for his shop.

Kareem is planning for the future to buy new machines managed by computer ,he also wish to improve his family's quality of life .

loans.use: to purchase a new machine for his shop

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mahmoud from Al-Ashrafia in Amman is 39 years old and the father of four children. He is a hard working man who runs a barber shop. 

He is requesting a 1,500 JOD loan and intends to use the amount to develop and expand his shop. Mahmoud also hopes to open another branch for his shop.

loans.use: To develop and expand his shop

loans.name: Sahel

texts.en:
Sahel A. D. (pictured here in FATEN's office) is a national Palestinian employee and a father of four daughters: Sally, Asma, Rasmiya and Dunia. He also has one son named Abdullah.

Seeing that his daughters were growing up, he wanted to make them their own room. So Sahel came to FATEN and is taking out a $3,000 loan to furnish and purchase the necessary items for the room.

loans.use: To furnish his daughters' room

loans.name: Tahreer

texts.en:
Tahreer T. (pictured here in FATEN's office) is 22 years old and a student from Tulkarem. She wants to finish school and start working so she can help her father take care of the family and help her younger brother finish school.

Tahreer came to FATEN and requested a $2,000 loan to pay school tuition fees and for school supplies. Tahreer's father is a national authority employee and will help her repay the loan.

loans.use: To pay school tuition fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a coffee roasting house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase kitchen tools and ingredients

loans.name: Ramadan

texts.en:
R. R., who is from Jabalia Refugee Camp and a father of two boys, has started a unique project in the camp: he has opened the first zoo in the Gaza Strip. R. wanted to give the children of the camp and the Gaza Strip a place where they could enjoy themselves.

R. used all his savings to make this project happen. Now he has come to FATEN to take a $2,000 loan to purchase tables and chairs for the zoo’s children's garden.

loans.use: To purchase chairs and tables

loans.name: Souk

texts.en: Mrs. Souk P., 48 years old, is a villager who lives in Khpob Veaeng village in Kandal province. She earns her living by two businesses which they are fish selling and vegetable selling in the local market. With her business, she stills earn less income to support her family.  In order to improve the family’s condition, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables, and more fish to enlarge her business activity. Her husband, Mr. Lor Oeun, 49 years old, works as construction worker. With their occupations, they are able to earn a little income to support the family. This couple has four children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory and the other two are attending school in the local village.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more vegetables, and more fish to enlarge her business activity.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Mr. Hong M. is a 28 year old married man, and is a villager who lives in Krabau village in Kandal province.  He is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice for a living. With this farming, he faces a problem because he does not have enough money to cultivate rice. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticide, and rice seed and hire laborers to plow his farm. His wife, Mrs. Par Eun, 30 years old, works as seamstress in a garment factory. This couple has two children: One is attending in a local school and the youngest one is a year old.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticide, and rice seed and hire laborers to plow his farm.

loans.name: Phath

texts.en:
Mrs. Phath T. is 42 years old, married to Mr. Heng Hy (on the right in the photo) and has four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one helps her parents with their businesses, one is attending the local school, while the youngest is five years old and not in school yet. Phath and her family live in Preaek Louk in Kandal province.

Phath and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land upon which they cultivate rice. Heng is also a fisherman. Because of the insufficient yield from their rice farm, Phath and her husband don’t have enough money to cultivate rice properly. So Phath would like to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline and to hire laborers to plow her farm for cultivation.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline and to hire farm laborers

loans.name: Tan

texts.en:
Mrs. Tan Y. is 48 years old, married to Mr. Vark Vith (pictured in the photo) and has six children: one is a laborer, one is a farmer and one is a rice seller, while the other three are attending the local school. She lives in Kbal Kaoh village in Kandal province.

Tan and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land upon which they cultivate rice, corn and peanuts to sell. She also sells rice and food in the market, while her husband is also a fisherman.

Tan and her husband find they don’t have enough money to properly grow their crops, so Tan would like to ask for a loan to buy rice seeds, bean seeds and fertilizers. With the rest of the loan she would like to buy a fishing boat for her husband.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, bean seeds, fertilizers and a fishing boat

loans.name: Sot Yom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sot Y., 57 years old, and her husband, Mr. Mey Moeun, are working hard to support their three children, one of whom is a farmer, one a motorbike mechanic and the youngest, a student in a local school. They live in Damrei Chhlang village in Kandal province.

Fifteen members of Damrei Chhlang village are taking on a bank loan and have selected Sot as the bank president. The members of this village loan will use their money to support different purposes.

Sot and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land upon which they cultivate rice. In order to properly cultivate their farm, Mrs. Sot Y. is requesting a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Net Pheap's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Net P., 43 years old, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land upon which she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Choun Sieb, fifty years old, is a fisherman and also helps his wife on the farm. This couple is working hard to support their five children: two are seamstresses in a garment factory, two are attending the local school, while the youngest is five years old and not in school yet. They live in Reang Dek village in Kandal province.

Five people are taking on a group loan and have selected Net as the group leader. The members of this group will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes. Net is asking for a loan to buy rice seed.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: Heang's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nine members living in Ta Hing village in Kandal province.  The members of this group selected Mrs. Heang S., a 40-year-old married woman, to be the group leader.  The members of this group will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Heang S. and her husband, Mr. Ngorn Nart, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate corn for a living. In order to support this farming, Mrs. Heang S. needs a loan to buy fertilizers, corn seeds, and gasoline. 

This couple is working hard to support their six children, four of whom are attending in the local school and the other two are 4-year-old twins.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, corn seeds, and gasoline to grown corn.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia M. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Cecilia is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Cecilia owns and operates a motorcycle transport business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport services in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Cecilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to make further repairs to a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Cecilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair transport vehicle

loans.name: Suon

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Suon P., age 46.  She lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns a  living raising pigs. This business has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. 

Mrs. Suon P. is married with three children, all of whom are single and are studying in the local school. Her husband sells firewood and charcoal in his village using his old motorbike.  He earns an income of approximately $6.40 per day. 

In order to earn extra income, Mrs. Suon P.’s husband wants to buy a larger quantity of firewood and charcoal to sell to retailers in the market.  However, he doesn’t have a vehicle large enough to transport more firewood and charcoal. To achieve this goal, Mrs. Suon P. has decided to seek a loan for her husband to purchase a trailer to connect to a motorbike so that he can use it to pick up more firewood and charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase trailer to transport charcoal for resale

loans.name: Mak's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of sixteen members.  They are located in Stueng village in Kandal province.  This village loan selected Mrs. Mak S., 50 years old, as the village bank president.  The members of this village hope that they will increase their income to improve their family's standard of living with these loans. 

Mrs. Mak S. and her husband, Mr. Va Vay, are farmers who own 1-hectare of land that they use to cultivate rice for their family's living.  With this farming, they do not have enough money to grow rice.  So Mrs. Mak S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to cultivate rice.  They also earn a living by working as farming laborers.  This spouse is working hard to support their six children: one of whom is a pure drinking water seller, one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the others are students in the local school who also supports their parent's farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Um Vy's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Um V., 52 years old, is a construction worker who receives a small salary to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Maen Tha, 50 years old, is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice with her husband’s help. This couple has eight children: two are farmers, two are laborers, and the others are students and help their parents on the farm. They live in Stueng village in Kandal province.

Thirteen members are taking on a village bank loan and have selected Um as the village’s bank president. The members of this village hope that they will increase their incomes and so improve their families’ living conditions through these loans.

Mr. Um V. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for laborers to plow the farm for cultivation.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for laborers to plow the farm

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Angelina M. runs a general store selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 50 years old, married and has four grown-up children. She is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. Angelina has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Angelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase products to sell. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Uch

texts.en:
Uch S. is a married man who currently lives in Kompong Tom province. He has four children, all of whom are single. He is currently a recycled materials trader -- he buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other provinces and countries. The used goods he deals in are mostly leftover electrical wires and plastic.

Uch S.'s wife is a rice trader. She buys rice in bulk from people who live in the village, stores the rice in her stock supply, and sells it later for profit.   

As the rice-harvesting season is approaching, Uch S. has decided to seek a loan to help his wife buy more rice during the time when rice is commanding its lowest price. Then she will sell it later when the price is higher.

loans.use: To stock up rice while prices are low for future sales

loans.name: Chhay's Group

texts.en:
Eight members are forming this village bank loan. They are located in Kandal Leu village in Kandal province. The members of this group selected Mrs. Chhay K., a 36-year-old married woman, as the village bank president.  The members of this group loan will use their portions of the loan to support their different needs. 

Mrs. Chhay K. earns her living by selling grocery in the local village. With this business, she earns a little income to improve her family.  She decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Chum RaT., is 36 years old.  He owns a battery charging machine and offers this service to villagers who have no access to electricity. With both their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their four children: three are attending the local school and the youngest one is 1 year old.

loans.use: To buy more grocery to enlarge business

loans.name: On's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. On S. earns her living by selling food in her village. Her husband, Mr. Phorn Hnork, is a bodyguard. Due to their careers not earning enough income to support the family, Mrs. On S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase groceries to sell. With her new business, she hopes that she will increase their income to improve the family's living conditions. This couple has a child who is attending a local school. 

This village bank includes ten members from Damnak Sangkae village in Kandal province. They selected Mrs. On S., 42 years old, as the village bank president. With their loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Hor

texts.en:
Hor L. is a 43-year-old married woman who earns a daily profit by selling rice in front of her house. She can make an average income of $1.20 a day to use for family expenses. 

Besides her rice shop, she has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. Because the pig-raising business is a good money-maker for Hor L. and her family, she has requested a loan of $400 to buy additional feed and more piglets to raise for sale during the period when pork is commanding the highest price.

Hor L. has a supporter and another financial source in her husband who works as a construction worker in the mobile phone area. The have five children, all of whom are single. One of them is working in the garment industry and has a regular monthly salary.

loans.use: To buy additional pigs to raise and feed for them.

loans.name: Yusunbaatar

texts.en: Yusunbaatar is 28 years old, married and father of two daughters. They all live together in a small wooden house in his parents-in-law’s plot of land in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His wife Bolortsetseg 33 works along with him. His eldest daughter Khongorzul, aged 9, attends a local secondary school and his youngest daughter stays at home.  Yusunbaatar is currently operating a bakery shop. He was a taxi driver for many years by using his own car. Yusunbaatar is very hardworking person with strong will and providing his children to give good education and morals. He is requesting 2.200.000 MNT loan to purchase a cake oven for his business.

loans.use: He is requesting 2.200.000 MNT loan to purchase a cake oven for his business.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria A. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 56 years old. Gregoria is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she makes and sells food and drinks in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately $63 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gregoria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Som

texts.en: From Kompong Tom province, Som R., age 26 is a married woman and mother who cares for two age-school student. She earns a living farming and raising pigs. She has been farming  since 2008. She  gets good results from  planting rice both in the rainy season and the dry season. She is married with two school-aged kids. Som R. has a life partner in her husband who is in building construction and earns a profit of about $2.50 each day. Currently, Som R. is looking for a loan to buy a cow because her older cow can no longer support her field work.

loans.use: To buy a cow to replace an older cow.

loans.name: Oun's Group

texts.en:
In Chey Otdam village in Kandal province, there are four members who have formed a  loan group. This loan group selected Mrs. Oun T., 54 years old, as the group leader. The members of this group will use their portions of the loan to support for different purpose. 

Mrs. Oun T. and her husband, Mr. Lot Larch, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate chili  to meet their family needs. With this farming they face a challange of insufficient money to cultivate chili. So in order to support this farming, Mrs. Oun T. would like to ask for a loan to buy chili plants and pay for the hiring of farm laborers for cultivating chili. This couple has a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy chili plants and pay for hire farming laborers for cultivating chili.

loans.name: Chly

texts.en:
Chly M. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 30 years old. Chly is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Chly owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Chly has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately PHP 5000 monthly for these activities.

In 2009, Chly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Chly is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Chly from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Horm

texts.en: Horm R. has been planting rice for a long time and she is a low-income person who presently lives in the province of Kompong Tom. She and her husband have spent most of their life time farming on their own farmland which they inherited from their grandparent. This couple has only one child  who works as a construction worker, and he shares his income with them to use for whole family’s needs. Currently, her son goes to his work place by riding his old motorbike. But now his motorbike has broken down. To solve this problem, Horm R. will use her loan to purchase a used motorcycle for her son to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle for driving to work.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita B. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 57 years old. Nenita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Nenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Ros P. is a married man who earns his living by planting a rice crop as well as by being a motor taxi driver for extra income. He and his family have been living in Kompong Tom province for several years. His wife assists him in the farming business. They are blessed with three children, one of whom is single. The other two are married, and have been employed in different jobs. 

Now, Ros P. has one child who doesn’t have a job yet, and he wants to help his child to have a proper occupation. He has decided to request this loan for his child to buy some goods like soft drinks, food, and a machine for squeezing sugar cane in order to get a fresh sugar juice for selling.

loans.use: To buy some goods like soft drinks, food, and a machine for squeezing sugar cane in order to get a fresh sugar juice to sell.

loans.name: Yuldosh

texts.ru: Артиков Юлдош проживает в районе Кубадиян. Ему 45 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Его дети взрослые. Они работают и живут самостоятельно. Сам Юлдош имеет среднее образование. Подрабатывает строительными работами по найму. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Кроме того у него имеется столовая, где он работает помощником повара. Уже год как занимается этим видом деятельности. Кредит берет для покупки необходимых принадлежностей и светомузыки. Он намерен расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Yuldosh A. lives in the Qubadiyon district. He is 45 years old, married with four grown children. His children work and live independently.Yuldosh has secondary education. He works part-time in construction work for hire where he has extensive experience. In addition, he works in a dining room as an assistant cook for over a year. He is asking for a loan for the purchase of necessary supplies, lights, and music. He intends to expand the activities of the dining room.

loans.use: Purchase of necessary supplies, lights, and music

loans.name: Phal

texts.en:
Phal S. is a 54-year-old widow woman who resides in the province of Kompong Tom. She has no life partner because her husband passed away many years ago. She now lives with eight children, six of whom are single and living under her management. The other two are married and living in their own houses already. Three of her kids are sewing workers in the local factory, and have a fixed salary every month.

Phal S. earns a living by raising pigs behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop.  In order to gain extra income, she will be using the loan to buy more pig feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his business

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
The young woman in the photograph is Ban R., age 60, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom, which has the best land for farming. She is a married woman who is devoted to her six children, four of whom are single and the other two are married. 

Ban R. owns a farm that she inherited from her grandmother where she grows various crops. She wants to plant a peanut crop in order to earn additional income. Her husband also helps her in the farming business. The beginning of this year is the best time for her to plant her peanuts, but she doesn’t have the funds to do it yet. To solve this problem, Ban R. would like a loan to buy some fertilizers, a pumping machine, and seeds for growing.

loans.use: To buy some fertilizers, a pumping machine, and seeds for growing.

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is a widow who lives in the municipality of Cordova in Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  making leather straps and a general store. 

Feliciana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Feliciana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly income of approximately $300, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 5th cycle loan, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for her business so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her businesses and for the renovation of their house. 

Feliciana is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								
								

"

loans.use: to fund the operation of her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Etibor

texts.ru: Артикова Этибор жительница Кубадиянского района. Ей 39 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Сын находится за границей на заработках. Сама Этибор имеет среднее образование. Более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа семян и клеенки для парника. На полученную прибыль хочет расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Etibor A. is a resident of Qubadiyon district. She is 39 years old, married with four children. Her son is working abroad. Etibor has a secondary education and for more than ten years has been involved in agriculture. Her house has a plot of land where they grow vegetables. She is asking for a loan for the purchase of seeds and cloth for the greenhouse. With her profits, she will expand her business operations.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and cloth for greenhouse

loans.name: Genevee

texts.en:
Genevee, a married mother of two children aged 9 and 12 years, lives in San Remegio, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two ventures: a fishing business and a cosmetic dealership. Her husband Rizalito, 43, works as a laborer to earn his living.

Genevee joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Genevee has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly income of PHP 10,300, uplifting the family's standard of living. She is now requesting a new loan to provide capital for her fishing business and to purchase more cosmetics to sell so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs and the education of her children. Genevee is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

Ely joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired to something better for her family. loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S. has been in the farming business since she was a single woman. Presently, she and her family live together in a small house in Kompong Tom province. She and her husband have been the local farmers since 1980. This couple has given birth to three children: two of the children are married and one is single. 

Ou S. and her husband grow rice and peanuts on their own farmland. They always get a great result from their planting. This is the second step for this couple to plant peanuts, but they don’t have enough money to support their farming yet. So Ou S. is seeking a loan to purchase a pumping machine and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase a pumping machine and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita F. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Benita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Benita operates a motorcycle transport business for local community members. Benita has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Benita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Benita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Benita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will also be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the fifth loan taken by Benita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng L. is 53 years old and a resident of the Kompong Tom province, Cambodia. She is married with six children, two of whom are married. Her husband, Kheil, is 55 years old. He is a local fisherman.

Seng L. makes a living cultivating rice and selling fresh fish in her community. She is currentL. earning around $1.50 a day. She has a few farmlands on which she doesn’t grow any crops yet, and she is going to grow peanuts, but her cash on hand is insufficient to do it. That is why Seng L. is applying for a loan as capital to allow her to purchase seeds and to hire the plowing machine to plow on her farmland so that she can start to plant.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and to hire a plow so she can start to plant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To finance a wedding party for his sons

loans.name: Nancy Kaptuiya

texts.en:
Nancy Kaptuiya C. is a 43 years old and married to Dickson C. a primary school teacher. They have been blessed with five children age between 14 years and 5 years. Nancy supports a family of 10 with the help of her husband.

Nancy runs a retail shop in Seretunin trading centre a few kilometers from Kabarnet town in Baringo County. She started this business 12 years ago as a food kiosk and her business grew so that now she operates a retail shop. This business gives her an average profit of Kshs 10,000 a month.  

Nancy has borrowed a loan of Kshs 40000 from KADET LTD being her fourth loan after successfully paying her previous loans. She intends to use the whole amount of loan to purchase stock for her retail shop. She anticipates using her profits to expand her business and save some for future. 

Her future dreams are to expand her business to a wholesale shop and be able to build rental houses and she also hopes to give her children the best education.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap E., married since 2006, has one son and lives with her mother on an island in the Mekong River, approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her husband is a motorcycle repairman.

A weaver for more than 20 years, Sopheap sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes thE. to sell in a Phnom Penh market. Sopheap hopes to continue her weaving business because it is a traditional profession and so is requesting another loan of $400 to purchase weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Keko Ole

texts.en:
Keko Ole K. is 53-years-old. He is married to Nanare K. and he is a father of six school going children. Keko is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last seven years.

He learnt about KADET from a colleague who is already a KADET registered client. This will be his second loan which he is planning to spend thirty thousand to prepare land for the next planting season and ten thousand to buy chemicals and fertilizers for his twenty acres of maize. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to hire more land for farming to increase his maize output and some part of the profit to develop his plot.

In future he plans to buy a bigger piece of land whereby he can be planting more maize in large scale. Keko believes he is hard working and by having the right resources at his disposal he can achieve a lot.

loans.use: to prepare land for the next planting season and spend ten thousand to buy chemicals and fertilizer for his twenty acres of maize.

loans.name: Song

texts.en:
Song H., 42, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. She is a housewife, while her husband is a carpenter earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses. Two of her children are employed at a factory and earn an income of USD 3 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and 15 on the children’s education.

Song is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase cows to raise for their offspring. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to purchase more cows to expand her business. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

Song appears in the photograph with her daughter.

loans.use: To buy cows to raise for their offspring

loans.name: Samonn

texts.en:
Mrs. Samonn T. (in the photo), 49, is single and lives with her sister and elderly mother on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her sister is a weaver. 

Samonn is a textile designer; she designs patterns for silk fabric. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase weaving materials for her sister and to renovate the house where she lives.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her sister and to renovate the house where she lives

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is a 38-year-old woman from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has four children, aged 19, 17, 12 and 9. Elsie raises crops for a living. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells to the market. Rice farming has been her family's source of income for more than a few years now. She hopes for her business to be stable.

Elsie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Elsie is requesting a new loan of 17,000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other inputs

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally M. (pictured with her loom), 43, is a widow with two sons and two daughters. She lives her sister, brother and parents on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her sister is a weaver and her brother is a security guard.  

Phally is a weaver. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her brother to get work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her brother to get work

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy new carpentry tools

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis K. is 61 years old married to Jane Chesire who is a housewife. He supports a family of 9 people which includes his seven children and wife. He runs a tailoring shop where he employs worker to design and make the clothes for him. He has been in this business for six years with a monthly income of Kshs 23,000.

Francis has borrowed a loan of Kshs 60,000 which he plans to use to purchase clothes and materials for his tailoring business and also use part of the money to buy goats for resale. He plans to save the anticipated profit so that he will buy a motorbike. This will be his fourth loan after he successfully repaid his previous loans. 

His future hopes are to diversify into other businesses by planting passion fruits and keeping poultry to increase family income. He also wants to train as a tailor because currently he is not very good at it and thus has to rely on the services of his employee who works for him.

loans.use: To buy materials for his tailoring business

loans.name: Kiwogo  Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: B. Sarah, 32 with hand raised, is affiliated with the Kiwogo development group-Mukono. She is married with two children and  has had her food sales business at a market stall in Butebe-Mukono for three years. Since the business took root, it's been hard work and perseverance throughout in the face of financial challenges which have affected her business in that she finds it hard to restock when she runs out of inventory. She believes this loan will come in really handy. Customers to her stall, where she sells vegetables and sweet potatoes are for the most part, local residents. The business generates her 80,000 shillings a week. With this loan, she will buy more foods to resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more foods to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: enlarge her house

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Um C. is a 39 year-old married woman who raises pigs to sell. She has been running this business since 2004. Um C. makes an income of approximately $1 per day. Her husband sells firewood in the village using his motorbike for transportation. He gets an average profit of $4 a day. In order to make more profit, Um C.’s husband wants to purchase a cart to connect to his old motorbike in order to buy and transport more firewood to sell. That is why Um C. would like to request a loan from Kiva. The couple has three school-aged kids.

loans.use: To purchase a cart to hitch to an old motorbike, and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Phakna

texts.en: Mrs. Phakna M. is 25 years old and her husband, Mr. Vebull Ni is 27 years old. They have been married since 2003 and have two daughters. The family lives on an island on Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh. In the past, Phakna was a weaver but  she quit her weaving business and now the family's main source of income is from her husband’s business. He is a wooden-house constructor. Phakna applies for a loan of $800 to repair the walls of her house and to build a restroom for family use.

loans.use: To repair the walls of her house and to build a restroom for family use.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel D. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 28 years old and married with two small children. To make a living, Maricel runs a general store selling both food and daily-use products. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Maricel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Maricel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly P. (who we see here in the photo) is 53 years old and has been married to her 52-year-old husband, Mr. Soeurng Sam, since 1979. They have eight children -- five sons and three daughters. Four are married and live on their own; of the other four, two have full-time jobs and the other two attend school. The family lives in a village approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital. 

Ly and her husband are rice farmers, and Mr. Soeurng Sam supplements the family income by selling cows and other farm animals. He buys his animals from districts located far from his home and sells them to middlemen who come to his house to buy them. She is applying for her first loan, for $1,000, to allow her husband to buy more livestock to resell.

loans.use: To expand her husband's livestock-selling business

loans.name: Ma. Loreta

texts.en:
Ma. Loreta T. lives in the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 45 years old, married and has five school-aged children. She makes a living by selling personal items and kitchen supplies to people who live in her area. Ma. Loreta has worked in this business for more than 15 years and earns about 2,500 PHP a month from her work.

In 2008, Ma. Loreta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI after using it to buy more supplies and increase her working capital. She is applying for a new loan, her fifth, to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Leap

texts.en: Mr. Leap Y. (who we see in the photo above) is 39 years old and married to Mrs. Chenla Say, who is 36 years old. They live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh, have been married since 1993 and have one daughter who works in a garment factory. Leap makes a living by driving a taxi and his wife works in a factory. He is applying for his first loan, for $1,000, to buy land adjacent to a parcel he already owns.

loans.use: to buy a piece of land adjacent to a parcel he already owns

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie G. is 40 years old, married, and has four school-aged children.  She is from the town of Sta. Josefa and is a rice farmer. She and her husband help each other build their business. Elvie wants to improve her family's living conditions. She hopes for their harvest to increase.

Elvie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Elvie is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP, which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers, and fuel for the tractor. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchas seeds, fertilizers, and fuel for the tractor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building materials

loans.name: Ley

texts.en:
Mrs. Ley S. (in the photo), 49, is a widow with three children: two sons and one daughter. The daughter is a garment-factory worker, one son is a security guard and another one is in school. She lives in a village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Ley sells vegetables in the local market. Her house is old and breaks down in some parts. She wants to repair it, but she does not have money. So she decided to ask for her first loan of $1,000 to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 38 years old and single.  He earns a living from dairy farming. It’s been four years since he started the business. He has managed to employ one person in his business.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to manage his finances. This has helped him to develop his business. He hopes to add more cows to his farm. 

He needs a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy animal feeds and to provide veterinary check-ups for the cows.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds and provide a veterinary check-up for his cows

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap N. (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Saroeun Penh, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980.

Sopheap is a weaver. Her husband is a marine. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting and to repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and to repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester M. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 30 years old and married with three children. To make a living, Ester owns and operates a motorcycle transport service business. Her main source of income comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport services to local community members. Ester is just starting this business.

Ester joined ASKI in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to repair her business vehicle. This loan is the first loan taken out by Ester from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve and expand her transportation business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair business vehicle

loans.name: Sam-Ol

texts.en:
